SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an objective summary of a text.
Content: Based on paragraphs 6 and 7 of The Signature of All Things, what is the 𝗠𝗢𝗦𝗧 𝗟𝗜𝗞𝗘𝗟𝗬 reason the author says “Alma suffered” in paragraph 6?

A.Choice: Alma feels betrayed and lonely.

B.Choice: Alma is afraid of being publicly humiliated.

C.Choice: Alma believes that she will never be successful.

D.Choice: Alma is unable to defend her words and actions.

SubTopics: Analyze how an author's choices concerning how to structure a text, order events within it (e.g., parallel plots), and manipulate time (e.g., pacing, flashbacks) create such effects as mystery, tension, or surprise.
Content: Read the sentences from The Signature of All Things in the box.

:box:• She had lost George Hawkes. (paragraph 7)

• George himself did not appear to realize that Alma had ever cared for him, nor that she might ever have suspected him of caring for her. (paragraph 8)
How does the second sentence 𝗠𝗔𝗜𝗡𝗟𝗬 relate to the first?

A.Choice: It reveals the irony that Alma was never in a relationship with George.

B.Choice: It develops intrigue about why George chose to marry somebody else.

C.Choice: It exposes the fact that George has been dishonest about his intentions.

D.Choice: It builds hostility because Alma will never forgive George for marrying her friend.

SubTopics: Determine the figurative or connotative meaning(s) of words and phrases as they are used in a text; analyze the impact of words with multiple meanings, as well as symbols or metaphors that extend throughout a text and shape its meaning.
Content: Read paragraph 8 of Emma in the box.

:box:“Yes, yes, pray pass me,” added her husband, with a sort of sneering consciousness; “I have nothing to say that can entertain Miss Woodhouse, or any other young lady. An old married man—quite good for nothing. Shall we walk, Augusta?”
Which word 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 describes Mr. Elton's tone in the paragraph?

A.Choice: serious

B.Choice: sarcastic

C.Choice: dismayed

D.Choice: discouraged

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grades 9–10 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: What is the 𝗠𝗢𝗦𝗧 𝗟𝗜𝗞𝗘𝗟𝗬 meaning of the word insolent as it is used in paragraph 12 of Emma?

A.Choice: clever

B.Choice: natural

C.Choice: uncertain

D.Choice: disrespectful

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Content: Read the sentences from the excerpts in the box.

:box:• There was nothing she could do to obliterate the passionate confessions she had so carelessly shared with Prudence over the years (and heavens, how she regretted them!), ... — paragraph 8 of The Signature of All Things

• “Yes, I see what she means, (turning to Mr. Knightley,) and I will try to hold my tongue.” — paragraph 6 of Emma
How does the purpose of the words in parentheses differ in the two sentences?

A.Choice: The words in parentheses provide an aside for the reader in The Signature of All Things, while they clarify a point of view in Emma.

B.Choice: The words in parentheses emphasize the depth of a character's feelings in The Signature of All Things, while they show a character's actions in Emma.

C.Choice: The words in parentheses stress a previously unmentioned idea in The Signature of All Things, while they reveal the impact of a character's words in Emma.

D.Choice: The words in parentheses help the reader understand the meanings of unknown terms in The Signature of All Things, while they highlight important details in Emma.

SubTopics: Analyze a case in which a character's point of view and actions signal acceptance or rejection of cultural norms or intellectual ideas of a period or place, drawing on a wide reading of world literature.
Content: Which characteristic is 𝗠𝗢𝗦𝗧 𝗖𝗟𝗘𝗔𝗥𝗟𝗬 shared by Alma in The Signature of All Things and Emma in Emma?

A.Choice: their impulsive reactions

B.Choice: their longing to get married

C.Choice: their jealousy of other women

D.Choice: their desire for a higher status

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an objective summary of a text.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Read the sentence from paragraph 16 of The Signature of All Things in the box.
:box:“But someday you will understand that nobody passes through this world without suffering—no matter what you may think of them and their supposed good fortune.”
Which idea does this sentence 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 help develop in the excerpt?

A.Choice: that perceptions sometimes differ from reality

B.Choice: that a personal support network can be invaluable

C.Choice: that the high expectations of others may be difficult to meet

D.Choice: that reflection is necessary to improve relationships with others

Content: Which sentence from Emma 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 illustrates an idea similar to the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “'Emma, I must once more speak to you as I have been used to do: a privilege rather endured than allowed, perhaps, but I must still use it.'” (paragraph 12)

B.Choice: “'Her situation should secure your compassion.'” (paragraph 17)

C.Choice: “He had misinterpreted the feelings which had kept her face averted, and her tongue motionless.” (paragraph 18)

D.Choice: “He had turned away, and the horses were in motion.” (paragraph 18)

SubTopics: Determine the figurative or connotative meaning(s) of words and phrases as they are used in a text; analyze the impact of words with multiple meanings, as well as symbols or metaphors that extend throughout a text and shape its meaning.
Content: Read the quotations from the excerpts and determine whether each quotation 𝗠𝗔𝗜𝗡𝗟𝗬 expresses insincerity, annoyance, or embarrassment.

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking; retain and further develop language skills learned in previous grades.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Apply knowledge of language to understand how language functions in different contexts, to make effective choices for meaning or style, and to comprehend more fully when reading or listening.

Write informative/explanatory texts (e.g., essays, oral reports, biographical feature articles) to examine and convey complex ideas, concepts, and information clearly and accurately through the effective selection, organization, and analysis of content.
Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.
Content: For this question, you will write an essay based on the passage(s). Write your essay in the space provided on the next two pages. Your writing should:

:ibox:• Present and develop a central idea/thesis.

• Provide evidence and/or details from the passage(s).

• Use correct grammar, spelling, and punctuation.

Based on the excerpts, write an essay explaining how Hanneke in The Signature of All Things and Mr. Knightley in Emma each play a significant role in the life of the main character. Be sure to use details from 𝗕𝗢𝗧𝗛 excerpts to develop your essay.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grades 9–10 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read the dictionary entry in the box.

:box:𝗦𝗜𝗡𝗘𝗪: n.

𝟭. a tendon

𝟮. the chief supporting force
Based on lines 9–15 of “Ndakinna,” which phrase 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the definition of sinew as “the chief supporting force”?

A.Choice: “with the wind eagle's eyes,” (line 10)

B.Choice: “... through a leather garment” (line 12)

C.Choice: “... strong to hold our people,” (line 13)

D.Choice: “close to the brown soil.” (line 15)

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an objective summary of a text.
Content: What is the 𝗠𝗔𝗜𝗡 effect of using the Abenaki names for bodies of water throughout “Naming Water”?

A.Choice: It highlights the unique habitats the different bodies of water support.

B.Choice: It pays tribute to the individual bodies of water that the Abenaki value.

C.Choice: It suggests the frequency with which the Abenaki travel on the bodies of water.

D.Choice: It describes the proximity the bodies of water have to important sites in the region.

SubTopics: Analyze how complex characters (e.g., those with multiple or conflicting motivations) develop over the course of a text, interact with other characters, and advance the plot or develop the theme.
Content: The speaker addresses “you” in each poem. How is the “you” in “Ndakinna” different from the “you” in lines 3 and 4 of “Naming Water”?

A.Choice: The speaker in “Ndakinna” addresses the elders, while the speaker in “Naming Water” addresses the trees.

B.Choice: The speaker in “Ndakinna” addresses the reader, while the speaker in “Naming Water” addresses the rivers.

C.Choice: The speaker in “Ndakinna” addresses visitors to the region, while the speaker in “Naming Water” addresses the reader.

D.Choice: The speaker in “Ndakinna” addresses future generations, while the speaker in “Naming Water” addresses the children of outsiders.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and analyze in detail its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an objective summary of a text.
Content: Both “Ndakinna” and “Naming Water” use imagery to describe the natural world. Based on the poems, choose the phrase that best completes each sentence.
In “Ndakinna,” the physical lines on a map 𝗠𝗔𝗜𝗡𝗟𝗬 convey the :DD-1:
In “Naming Water,” the bodies of water are 𝗠𝗔𝗜𝗡𝗟𝗬 described as tracing :DD-2:
The imagery that appears in the poems suggests that the land and the bodies of water are :DD-3:

3:C.Choice: forces to be tamed and possessed.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and analyze how an author uses rhetoric to advance that point of view or purpose.
Content: In paragraph 6 of “He Needs to Be a Kid,” what does the repetition of the phrase “even if” highlight?

A.Choice: that the publicity Neiko receives is undeserved

B.Choice: that Neiko is too young to resist the temptations of fame

C.Choice: that there is a disparity between Neiko's abilities and his age

D.Choice: that those seeking to influence Neiko's career may have hidden motives

SubTopics: Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what a text states explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 43 of “He Needs to Be a Kid” in the box.
:box:Mundey is constantly straddling the line between wanting Neiko to succeed and shielding him from people who want to profit off that.
Which detail from the article 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 describes an example of Mundey “straddling the line”?

A.Choice: “'You want to play basketball and football when you're older, right?' Mundey asked him, and just the mention of basketball caused Neiko to perk up.” (paragraph 31)

B.Choice: “'Good,' Mundey said as she leaned back in her chair.” (paragraph 37)

C.Choice: “Mundey was recently contacted by an agent offering to be Neiko's mentor.” (paragraph 46)

D.Choice: “Mundey did not want to use the names of those who have contacted her about Neiko, worried that they could hold it against her son in the future.” (paragraph 48)

SubTopics: Analyze in detail how an author's ideas or claims are developed and refined by particular sentences, paragraphs, or larger portions of a text (e.g., a section or chapter).
Content: Which statement 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 explains how paragraphs 56 and 57 of “He Needs to Be a Kid” support an idea that is developed throughout the article?

A.Choice: Paragraph 56 shows Neiko as a kid caught up in the thrill of a game, while paragraph 57 shows how seriously he takes the game.

B.Choice: Paragraph 56 shows how Neiko benefits from basketball, while paragraph 57 shows how others benefit from playing with him.

C.Choice: Paragraph 56 shows Neiko disengaging from his fans, while paragraph 57 shows his anxiety about winning the game.

D.Choice: Paragraph 56 shows that Neiko plays basketball regularly, while paragraph 57 shows that he thinks like an adult.

SubTopics: Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grades 9–10 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 7 of “Committing to Play for a College” in the box.

:box:It is generally traced back to the professionalization of college and youth sports, a shift that has transformed soccer and other recreational sports from after-school activities into regimens requiring strength coaches and managers.
Based on the sentence, which phrase best defines the word regimen?

A.Choice: a program directed by parents

B.Choice: a program financed by outsiders

C.Choice: a program with demanding expectations

D.Choice: a program that offers relaxation techniques

SubTopics: Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what a text states explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Based on “Committing to Play for a College,” what is the 𝗠𝗔𝗜𝗡 reason some young female soccer players feel pressured to accept scholarships early?

A.Choice: The players want to be noticed.

B.Choice: The players are interested in other sports.

C.Choice: The players fear losing opportunities to others.

D.Choice: The players are too good for middle school athletics.

SubTopics: Analyze in detail how an author's ideas or claims are developed and refined by particular sentences, paragraphs, or larger portions of a text (e.g., a section or chapter).
Content: Which statement 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 describes how paragraph 7 of “He Needs to Be a Kid” and paragraph 6 of “Committing to Play for a College” serve a similar function in each article?

A.Choice: Both explore the concerns of an academic audience.

B.Choice: Both link an individual's experience to a broader issue.

C.Choice: Both appeal to the reader's previously formed attitudes.

D.Choice: Both insert a counterargument into a larger explanation.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an objective summary of a text.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Which negative impact of early recruiting is the focus of paragraph 21 of “He Needs to Be a Kid”?

A.Choice: the continuing expansion of the practice to lower grades

B.Choice: the profitability of the practice for agents who engage in it

C.Choice: the potential for dishonesty among coaches who participate

D.Choice: the inherent unfairness of the evaluation system used by scouts

Content: Which detail from “Committing to Play for a College” 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 provides additional evidence of the negative impact identified in the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “The heated race to recruit ever younger players has drastically accelerated over the last five years, according to the coaches involved.” (paragraph 7)

B.Choice: “The practice has attracted little public notice, except when it has occasionally happened in football and in basketball.” (paragraph 8)

C.Choice: “But these rules have enormous and widely understood loopholes.” (paragraph 18)

D.Choice: “Scouts were given a hospitality tent as well as a special area next to the team benches, not accessible to parents, to set up their folding chairs.” (paragraph 29)

SubTopics: Analyze how an author unfolds an analysis or series of ideas or events, including the order in which the points are made, how they are introduced and developed, and the presence or absence of connections between them.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.

In both articles, the authors develop the idea that parents may have conflicting feelings about their children's involvement in activities that draw attention from recruiters. Select one detail from each article that shows these conflicting feelings.
Select one detail from “He Needs to Be a Kid” that shows conflicting feelings.

A.Choice: “'Oh, look look look,' Michelle Mundey, his mother, whispered from the other end of the court. 'That kid is at least 13, maybe 14.'” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “'You know, baby,' Mundey said, laughing, as she ran the laces through her hands. 'Soon you'll be dunking.'” (paragraph 10)

C.Choice: “Mundey started and runs an Instagram account for Neiko—which has more than 1,500 followers—and sometimes posts videos of him missing a shot to remind his followers that he is 9.” (paragraph 40)

Content: Select one detail from “Committing to Play for a College” that shows conflicting feelings.

A.Choice: “At the recent event, in an Orlando suburb, an estimated 600 college coaches attended as 158 teams played on 17 fields over the course of three days.” (paragraph 28)

B.Choice: “Nearly every youth club had a pamphlet—handed out by a parent during the games—with a head shot, academic records, soccer achievements and personal contact information for each player.” (paragraph 29)

C.Choice: “'Is it a little bit sick? Yeah,' he said. 'You are a little young to do this, but if you don't, the other kids are going to.'” (paragraph 34)

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking; retain and further develop language skills learned in previous grades.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Apply knowledge of language to understand how language functions in different contexts, to make effective choices for meaning or style, and to comprehend more fully when reading or listening.
Write arguments (e.g., essays, letters to the editor, advocacy speeches) to support claims in an analysis of substantive topics or texts, using valid reasoning and relevant and sufficient evidence.
Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.
Content: For this question, you will write an essay based on the passage(s). Write your essay in the space provided on the next two pages. Your writing should:

:ibox:• Present and develop a central idea/thesis.

• Provide evidence and/or details from the passage(s).

• Use correct grammar, spelling, and punctuation.

Based on “He Needs to Be a Kid” and “Committing to Play for a College,” write a speech to deliver at a school assembly that argues against the practice of early recruiting of young athletes. Be sure to include information from 𝗕𝗢𝗧𝗛 articles to develop your speech.

SubTopics: Cite strong and thorough textual evidence to support analysis of what a text states explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Based on paragraph 11 of “The Quiet Ways Automation Is Remaking Service Work,” which statement 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 explains the author's worry that automation “masks time”?

A.Choice: Employees usually try harder when their work is appreciated.

B.Choice: It is easier to undervalue the work a person does when it is not clearly visible.

C.Choice: It is easy for consumers to feel overwhelmed by the variety of conveniences available.

D.Choice: Customers are more likely to purchase something if they appreciate how it was made.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and analyze its development over the course of the text, including how it emerges and is shaped and refined by specific details; provide an objective summary of a text.
Content: Read paragraph 10 of “Welcome to the Automated Warehouse of the Future” in the box.

:box:But while the focus here is on technological advances, on more and more automation, we shouldn't forget that in the middle of these machines— metaphorically and literally, in the case of the Andover warehouse—there are humans.
Based on the article, how does the paragraph 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 support a main idea of the article?

A.Choice: It introduces the idea that human workers are confused about the machines that are taking their jobs.

B.Choice: It develops the idea that human workers will ultimately decide how effectively they work with the machines.

C.Choice: It emphasizes the idea that there are humans who feel excited about working in the same industries as machines.

D.Choice: It reinforces the idea that there are humans who work to create and improve the machines as well as work alongside them.

SubTopics: Analyze in detail how an author's ideas or claims are developed and refined by particular sentences, paragraphs, or larger portions of a text (e.g., a section or chapter).
Content: Which claim is 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 developed by paragraph 11 of “Welcome to the Automated Warehouse of the Future”?

A.Choice: There are inconsistencies in how human workers interact with automation.

B.Choice: There are contradictory viewpoints about how automation will affect human employees.

C.Choice: Despite the recent trends in innovation, automation design will never surpass human capabilities.

D.Choice: While advancements in automation have been made, there are many tasks that still require human intervention.

SubTopics: Analyze how an author unfolds an analysis or series of ideas or events, including the order in which the points are made, how they are introduced and developed, and the presence or absence of connections between them.
Content: Which detail from “Welcome to the Automated Warehouse of the Future” 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 explains why companies use automation?

A.Choice: “[The robots'] job is to be cheaper and more efficient than humans, and they are very good at it.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “But [the robots'] actions are all coordinated by a central computer.” (paragraph 7)

C.Choice: “And although they can't yet handle bags of oranges (or any other delicate, or irregularly shaped items), Ocado is working on a solution.” (paragraph 12)

D.Choice: “But experts say the technology being incubated here will be adopted by other sectors.” (paragraph 15)

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Content: Read the sentences from the articles in the box.

:box:• More hotels are offering automated check-in via app or even—in China—via facial recognition. (paragraph 2 of “The Quiet Ways Automation Is Remaking Service Work”)

• The tasks being undertaken by Ocado's bots are so basic they're best described by simple verbs—“lifting,” “moving,” “sorting”—and that means they exist in various forms in a range of industries. (paragraph 2 of “Welcome to the Automated Warehouse of the Future”)
What is the 𝗠𝗢𝗦𝗧 𝗟𝗜𝗞𝗘𝗟𝗬 purpose of the dashes in the sentences?

A.Choice: to set off specific examples

B.Choice: to offer historical information

C.Choice: to introduce new perspectives

D.Choice: to emphasize academic language

SubTopics: Determine the meaning(s) of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings; analyze the cumulative or contradictory impact of specific word choices on meaning and tone (e.g., how the language of a court opinion differs from that of a newspaper; how an author's word choice varies from one part of a text to another).
Content: Read the sentence from paragraph 7 of “The Quiet Ways Automation Is Remaking Service Work” in the box.
:box:Rather than fully replacing human workers with The Jetsons-style robots, the service industry is more likely to adopt a system of partial automation.
Which detail from “Welcome to the Automated Warehouse of the Future” 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 illustrates “partial automation” in the warehouse industry?

A.Choice: “Humans do the unpacking and packing, while in the middle, robots sort and rearrange this vast inventory 24 hours a day.” (paragraph 6)

B.Choice: “And if any individual robot breaks down, it doesn't matter, because any of the other bots can do its job; they're all interchangeable.” (paragraph 8)

C.Choice: “For that, Ocado is developing a soft robotic hand that uses rubber fingers filled with pressurized air.” (paragraph 13)

D.Choice: “One named Embodied Intelligence uses AI to create robots that learn by watching humans.” (paragraph 14)

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is valid and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; identify false statements or incomplete truths and fallacious reasoning.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
What is the central argument in “The Quiet Ways Automation Is Remaking Service Work”?

A.Choice: Automation in the service industry has been accelerated due to customer demands.

B.Choice: Employees in the service industry are concerned about losing their jobs to automation.

C.Choice: Automation in the service industry has been complicated by obstacles to technological efficiency.

D.Choice: Employees in the service industry are optimistic about the ways automation can aid with specific tasks.

Content: Which detail from “Welcome to the Automated Warehouse of the Future” provides the 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 𝗖𝗢𝗨𝗡𝗧𝗘𝗥𝗔𝗥𝗚𝗨𝗠𝗘𝗡𝗧 to the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “In a traditional warehouse where items are scattered around on distant shelves, this process can take hours.” (paragraph 7)

B.Choice: “As well as the boost to speed, the hive-grid-machine has the advantages of being scalable and modular.” (paragraph 8)

C.Choice: “Well-funded startups are also building their own solutions.” (paragraph 14)

D.Choice: “He points out that even in industries that have invested heavily in automation, such as car manufacturing, there are still lots of humans involved.” (paragraph 18)

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Delineate and evaluate the argument and specific claims in a text, assessing whether the reasoning is valid and the evidence is relevant and sufficient; identify false statements or incomplete truths and fallacious reasoning.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.

In “Welcome to the Automated Warehouse of the Future,” the author claims that there is a “wave of automation slowly hitting countries around the world.” Select one detail from 𝗘𝗔𝗖𝗛 article that provides evidence for the author's claim.
Select one detail from paragraphs 1–3 of “The Quiet Ways Automation Is Remaking Service Work” that provides evidence for the author's claim.

A.Choice: “... demands such as wage increases and better hours are usually the objective.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “Marriott employees are right to worry.” (paragraph 2)

C.Choice: “... robots that take over bartending and salad-making duties on cruise ships and in airports, and that deliver food to hotel guests' rooms.” (paragraph 2)

D.Choice: “The Marriott workers' priorities included updated language for health care and buyout packages.” (paragraph 3)

Content: Select one detail from paragraphs 16–18 of “Welcome to the Automated Warehouse of the Future” that provides evidence for the author's claim.

A.Choice: “'[Picking] is an issue that people are trying to solve for lots and lots of different use cases,' ...” (paragraph 16)

B.Choice: “A report by PWC found that in the UK alone, just under 1 million logistics workers are at risk of having their jobs automated in the next 15 years.” (paragraph 17)

C.Choice: “'... that's not something we're going to get to in the foreseeable future.'” (paragraph 18)

D.Choice: “'... it's just the same journey we've been on since day one...'”
